text:
Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1 entitled "Planner Status: Past and Present" was distributed to all Saskatchewan Planners in 1964. It included questions about personal experiences, professional development, and future plans.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who have had personal experience with the planning profession in Saskatchewan. It is not intended for persons who have never been involved in planning activities.

If more than two members of the family can answer the questions, they should write their names separately instead of writing for a separate questionnaire.

22nd Questionnaire

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1 entitled "Planner Status: Past and Present" was distributed to all Saskatchewan Planners in 1964. It included questions about personal experiences, professional development, and future plans.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who have had personal experience with the planning profession in Saskatchewan. It is not intended for persons who have never been involved in planning activities.

If more than two members of the family can answer the questions, they should write their names separately instead of writing for a separate questionnaire.

I am not sure.

Poveshell, Do you still archive?

Signature:

Date:
1. Your full name: Hugh Sutherland Burt
2. Your address: R.R. #4, Burt, 1952
3. Date: March 2nd, 1952
4. Where were you born? (Give place or place and country)
   Jameson, Scotland
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   Charles Sutherland, Highland Railway employee
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   April, 1905
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates whenever possible.
   B.C., 1901; 1902; South Africa, 1903; 1904; B.C., 1904; 1905
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to edit.)
   23 years
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   Free homestead and fresh air
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)
    Government information
1. Your full name: Hugh Sutherland Burt
2. Your address: R.R. #1, Burt, Sask.
3. Date: March 20th, 1952
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

Free homeland and fresh air

Government information

How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Mail order or government information?)
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
They thought I arrived fairly & death.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?
Alone

13. What means of transportation did you use?
C.P.R.

14. What incidents of the journey best do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
In 1901 I came from Regina to Craik to visit some relatives. Craik at that time consisted of a station and water tank. The station area was very pleasant. I remember seeing the train going out in two to climb the Dundas Hill. The coaches looked like birds and one of the passengers going out to shoot chicken.

15. Where did you first settle when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
1905 Saskatoon

16. Where did you settle or take up land in the Park Bull district Humboldt?

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came? Mining, herd rock, sailing, farming
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

My thoughts: I arrived freely & death.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other groups)?

Alone

13. What means of transportation did you use?

C.P.R.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents, or other experiences).

In 1901 I came from Regina to Craik to visit some relatives. Craik at that time consisted of a station and water tank. The station was an easy place, the only incident I remember was the tram dairy cut in two to climb the Dundas Hill. The coaches barely got behind, and one of the passengers going out to check chicken.

15. Where did you first stop when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

1905 Saskatoon

16. Where did you settle or take up land in the Park Belt district?

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Mining, hard rock, sailing, farming
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

About once a month.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Married Harry Elizabeth Murray, June 30th, 1907.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? It was a place to settle.

I think perhaps two.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.

3 Brothers: 1. 1905; 2. 1906; 3. 1907

2 Sisters: 1. 1913; 2. Came to Saskatoon and worked for C.P.R.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

The spring of 1907. The snow was still on the ground in May, and the crops were well grown in September, we had 2 feet of snow for it.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting relatives, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

We traveled only locally by wagon and train attending church and visiting friends.
3.

19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

about once a month

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Married Mary Elizabeth Stanley, June 30th, 1907

21. Did anyone else come to Canada because of your recommendation? If so, who?

I think perhaps two

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came here:

3 Brothers: 1, 1906; 1, 1906; 1, 1906

2 Sons: 1, 1913; 1, came to Saskatchewan and worked for C.P.R. 3 Ashis: 1, Keokuk, Iowa

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

The spring crop in 1907 was poor and still on the ground in late May and the crops were well green in September, we had a terrible fall.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For instance, attending church, visiting relatives, etc.) How often? How long by what means of travel?

we traveled only locally by wagon and train attending church and visiting friends
